turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Karen.  I haven't been pleasant this weekend.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: We've all seemed a little tense lately...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Come to think of it, I haven't been very pleasant for weeks. For that, I'm truly sorry. More than any two people I know, I don't want you and Lloyd to be angry with me...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: We're never deeply angry, we just get sore. The way you do. We know you too well...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: So many people - know me. I wish I did. I wish someone would tell be about me...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: You're Margo. Just - Margo.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: And what is that? Besides something spelled out in light bulbs, I mean. Besides something called temperament, which consists mostly of swooping about on a broomstick creaming at the top of my voice... infants behave the way I do, you know. They carry on and misbehave - they'd get drunk if they knew how - when they can't have what they want. When they feel unwanted and insecure - or unloved.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: What about Bill?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: What about Bill?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: He's in love with you.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: More than anything in this world, I love Bill. And I want Bill. I want him to want me. But me. Not Margo Channing. And if I can't tell they apart - how can he?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Why should he - and why should you?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Bill's in love with Margo Channing. He's fought with her, worked with her, loved her... but ten years from now - Margo Channing will have ceased to exist. And what's left will be... what?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Margo. Bill is all of eight years younger than you.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Those years stretch as the years go on. I've seen it happen too often.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Not to you. Not to Bill.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Isn't that what they always say?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I don't suppose the heater runs when the motor doesn't?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Silly, isn't it? You'd think they'd fix it so people could just sit in a car and keep warm...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: About Eve. I've acted pretty disgracefully toward her, too.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Well...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Let's not fumble for excuses, not here and now with my hair down. At best, let's say I've been oversensitive to... well, to the fact that she's so young - so feminine and helpless. To so many things I want to be for Bill... funny business, a woman's career. The things you drop on your way up the ladder, so you can move faster. You forget you'll need them again when you go back to being a woman. That's one career all females have in common - whether we like it or not - being a woman. Sooner or later we've all got to work at it, no matter what other careers we've had or wanted... and, in the last analysis, nothing is any good unless you can look up just before dinner or turns around in bed - and there he is. Without that, you're not woman. You're something with a French provincial office or a book full of clippings - but you're not a woman...  ... slow curtain. The end.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Margo.  Margo, I want you to know how sorry I am about this...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: About what?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: This. I can't tell you how sorry I am!

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Don't give it another thought, one of destiny's many pranks. After all, you didn't personally drain the gasoline out of the tank...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: "... my hat which has, lo, these many seasons become more firmly rooted about my ears, is lifted to Miss Harrington. I am once more available for dancing in the streets and shouting from the housetops." ... I thought that one went out with Woollcott...  Down here... here, listen to this- "... Miss Harrington had much to tell - and these columns shall report her faithfully - about the lamentable practice in our Theater of permitting, shall we say - mature - actresses to continue playing roles requiring a youth and vigor of which they retain but a dim memory-"

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: I just can't believe it.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: It get better! "- About the understandable reluctance on the part of our entrenched First Ladies of the Stage to encourage, shall we say - younger - actresses; about Miss Harrington's own long and unsupported struggle for opportunity-"

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: I can't believe Eve said those things!

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: In this rat race, everybody's guilty till they're proved innocent! One of the differences between the Theater and civilization...  ... what gets me is how all of those papers in town happened to catch that particular performance!

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Lloyd says it's a publicity release...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: The little witch must have had Indians runners out snatching critics out of bars, steam rooms and museums or wherever they hole up... well, she won't get away with it! Nor will Addison deWitt and his poison pen! If Equity or my lawyer can't or won't do anything about it, I will personally stuff that pathetic little lost lamb down Mr. deWitt's ugly throat...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Karen, in all the years of our friendship, I have never let you go to the Ladies' Room alone. But now I must. I am busting to know what goes on in that feverish little brain waiting there...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Well... all right.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: With tears?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: With tears.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: But not right away? First the business of fighting them off, chin up, stout fella...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Check.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Very classy stuff, lots of technique-

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: I remember.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: You'll be there, won't you.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: How was the concert?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Loud.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: - 'at's my loyal little woman.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: The critics thought so, the audiences certainly think so - packed houses, tickets for months in advance - I can't see that either of Lloyd's last two plays have hurt you any!

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Easy, now...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: You can't put her out, I promised... Margo, you've got to see her, she worships you, it's like something out of a book-

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: That book is out of print, Karen, those days are gone. Fans no longer pull the carriage through the streets - they tear off clothes and steal wrist watches...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: If you'd only see her, you're her whole life - you must have spotted her by now, she's always there...

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Now let's not get into a big hassle-

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: It's about time we did! It's about time Margo realized that what's attractive on stage need not necessarily be attractive off.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Coming?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: In a minute...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Lloyd, what happened...?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Up to here! That's where I've got it - up to here! Of all the star ridden, presumptuous, hysterical-

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Margo, again...

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: And again and again! Two hours late for the audition, to begin with-

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: That's on time for Margo.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Then a childish, heavy-handed routine about not knowing Eve was her understudy-

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: It's just possible she didn't...

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Of course she knew! For one thing, Addison told her how superbly Eve had read the part-!  Karen, let me tell you about Eve. She's got everything - a born actress. Sensitive, understanding, young, exciting, vibrant-

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: - don't run out of adjectives, dear.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: - everything a playwright first thinks of wanting to write about... until his play becomes a vehicle for Miss Channing...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Margo hasn't done badly by it.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Margo. Margo's great. She knows it. That's the trouble. She can play Peck's Bad Boy all she wants, and who's to stop her? Who's to give her that boot in the rear she needs and deserves?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: It's going to be a cozy weekend.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: What is?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: We're driving out to the country tomorrow night. Just the four of us. Bill, Margo, you and I...

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Well. We've spent weekends before with nobody talking...  ... just be sure to lock up all blunt instruments and throwable objects...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: What time is it?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: When you asked a minute ago it was five-forty-two. It is now five forty-three. When you ask a minute from no, it will be-

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: I just don't want Margo to miss her train. As it is, she'll barely make the theater...

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Five-fifty-five. We'll be at the station in plenty of time...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Lloyd, be careful...

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Just a little skid, that's all. This road's like glass.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: But it can't be! We can't be out of gas! I filled it myself yesterday!  Wasn't it full when you drove to Brewster this morning?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: I guess I didn't look. You know I don't pay attention to those things...

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Incredible.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: You'll break your neck on that ice.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: What a way to die - trying to get an actress to the theater in time. Tell Max I want to be buried with royalties...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Don't joke about such things.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: - it's Addison, from start to finish, it drips with his brand of venom... taking advantage of a kid like that, twisting her words, making her say what he wanted her to say-

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Where'd you get all that information?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Eve.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Eve?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: She's been to see me, as a matter of fact she left just before you came in - you just missed her...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: That was a pity...

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: She wanted to explain about her interview, wanted to apologize to someone - and didn't dare face Margo...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: I wonder why.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: You know, I've been going over our financial condition - if you'll pardon the expression...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: That's quite a change of subject.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: What with taxes coming up - and since I'm a playwright and not an oil well operator - well, I've been thinking...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: I'm trying hard to follow you.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: If - instead of waiting until next season to do 'Footsteps on the Ceiling', which is in pretty good shape - and if Margo can be talked into going on tour with 'Aged in Wood' - we could put 'Footsteps...' into production right away...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: I'm beginning to catch up.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: If we could cast it properly, that is...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Maybe get some younger actress for the part? Someone who'd look the part as well as play it?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: You've got to admit it would be a novelty.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Now you're quoting Addison. Or Eve.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Eve did mention the play, you know. But just in passing - she's never ask to play a part like "Cora," she'd never have the nerve...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Eve would ask Abbott to give her Costello.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: No, I got the idea myself - while she was talking to me...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: With gestures, of course.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: For once, to write something and have it realized completely. For once, not to compromise-

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Lloyd Richards, you are not to consider giving that contemptible little worm the part of "Cora."

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Now just a minute-

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Margo Channing has not been exactly a compromise all these years, half the playwrights in the world would give their shirts for that particular compromise!

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Now just a minute!

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: It strikes me that Eve's disloyalty and ingratitude must be contagious!

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: All this fuss and hysteria because an impulsive kid got carried away by excitement and the conniving of a professional manure slinger named deWitt! She apologized, didn't she?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: On her knees, I have no doubt! Very touching, very Academy-of-Dramatic Arts!

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: That bitter cynicism of yours is something you've acquired since you left Radcliffe!

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: The cynicism you refer to, I acquired the day I discovered I was different from little boys!

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Margo - and Bill - want us to meet them at the Cub Room tonight, after theater. For a bottle of wine.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Margo in the Cub Room. I couldn't be more surprised if she'd said Grant's Tomb.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: I'm glad Bill's back.

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: They'd die without each other.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Darling, I didn't promise Eve anything. Just said I thought she'd be fine for the part, but there were some practical difficulties...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Such as?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: You - for one. I told her you were set on Margo playing the part - and I certainly wouldn't make a change without your approval.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Well of all-

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Margo!

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Three days, that's for the bourgeois - I see a midnight elopement, waking up a village person...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: What are you going to wear?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: After all, maybe she just wants to apologize...

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: I have no possible interest in anything she'd have to say.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: - well? What happened?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Nothing much. She apologized.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: You mean - all this time - she'd done nothing but apologize? What'd you say?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Not much.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: What's so funny?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Nothing...

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Who is it? What's it all about?

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Did Miss Harrington tell you to call Mr. Richards?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: I didn't think you would! It seems to me, Karen, that for some tine, now, you've been developing a deep unconcern for the feeling of human being in general-

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: I'm a human being, I've got some!

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: - and for my feelings in particular! For my play, my career - and now for a frightened, hysterical girl on the eve of her first night in the Theater!

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Have you forgotten about Eve? What she is, what she's done?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Old wives' tales, born of envy and jealousy! And a phobia against truth!

turns.speaker: KAREN
turns.text: Then tell me this isn't true! That your concern for your play and career is one thing - and that poor frightened hysterical girl another - and that your concern for her has nothing to do with either your play or your career!

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Honey chili had a point. You know, I can remember plays about women - even from the South - where it never even occurred to them whether they wanted to marry their fathers more than their brothers...

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: That was way back...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Within your time, buster. Lloyd, honey, be a playwright with guts. Write me one about a nice, normal woman who shoots her husband.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Would you, really? How sweet-

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: I doubt very much that you'd like her in 'The Hairy Ape'.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: How about calling it a night?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: And you pose as a playwright. A situation pregnant with possibilities - and all you can think of is everybody to go to sleep...

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: I like that girl. That quality of quiet graciousness...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: ... Among so many quiet qualities.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: The general atmosphere is very Macbethish. What has or is about to happen?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: What is he talking about?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: There you are, both of you. Max, Karen has decided it's time to go.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Where is she?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Up in the room.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Who's left out there?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Too many. And you've got a new guest. A movie star from Hollywood.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Shucks. And my autograph book is at the cleaners.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: You disapprove of me when I'm like this, don't you?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Not exactly. Sometimes, though, I wish I understood you better.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: When you do, let me in on it.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: I will.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: How's the new one coming?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: The play? All right, I guess...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: "Cora." She's - still a girl of twenty?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Twentyish. It isn't important.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Don't you think it's about time it became important?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: How do you mean?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Don't be evasive.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Margo, you haven't got any age.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Miss Channing is ageless. Spoken like a press agent.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: I know what I'm talking about, after all they're my plays...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Spoken like an author.  Lloyd, I'm not twentyish. I am not thirtyish. Three months ago, I was forty years old. Forty. Four oh.  That slipped out, I hadn't quite made up my mind to admit it. Now I feel as if I'd suddenly taken all my clothes off...

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Week after week, to thousands of people, you're as young as you want...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: ... as young as they want, you mean. And I'm not interested in whether thousands of people think I'm six or six hundred-

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Just one person. Isn't that so?  You know what this is all about, don't you? It has very little to do with whether you should play "Cora" - it has everything to do with the fact that you've had another fight with Bill.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: She's your understudy.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Eve? Eve, my understudy? But I had no idea...

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: I thought you knew... She was put on over a week ago-

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: It seems almost inconceivable that I haven't seen her backstage, but with so many people loitering around... well, well. So Eve is not working for Max after all-  - Max you sly puss.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I'm sure you underestimate yourself, Eve. You always do.  You were about to tell me about Eve...

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: You'd have been proud of her.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I'm sure.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: She was a revelation...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: To you, too?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I mean, among other things, that it must have been a revelation to have your twenty-four-year-old character played by twenty-four-year-old actress...

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: That's beside the point.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: It's right to the point. Also that it must have sounded so new and fresh to you - so exciting to have the lines read as you wrote them!

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: You've been talking to that venomous fishwife, Addison deWitt-

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: - in this case, apparently, as trustworthy as the World Almanac!

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: You knew when you came in that the audition was over, that Eve was your understudy! Playing that childish game of cat and mouse...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Not mouse, never mouse! If anything - rat!

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: You have a genius for making barroom brawl out of a perfectly innocent misunderstanding at most!

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Perfectly innocent! Man have been hanged for less! I'm lied to, attacked behind my back, accused of reading your silly dialogue inaccurately - as if it were Holy Gospel!

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: I never said it was!

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Then you listened as if someone else had written you play - whom did you have in mind? Sherwood? Arthur Miller? Beaumont and Fletcher?

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: I shall never understand the weird process by which a body with a voice suddenly fancies itself a mind! Just when exactly does an actress decide they're her words she's saying and her thoughts she's expressing?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Usually at the point when she's got to rewrite and rethink them to keep the audience from leaving the theater!

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: It's about time the piano realized it has not written the concerto!

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Karen and I just don't want an accident-

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: I have no intention of having an accident!

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: It's not important whether you do. We are wearing long underwear.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: How fortunate that I have an understudy so ready, so willing and so able to go on.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: The audience will want its money refunded, believe me.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Thank you, Lloyd. Godspeed.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: It's been quite a night. I understand that your understudy - Miss Harrington - has given her notice.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Too bad.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: City Hall, that's for prize fighters, and reporters - I see a cathedral, a bishop, banks of flowers...

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: Very discreet. A note right out in the open like that. Next time tell your lover to blow smoke rings - or tap a glass...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Lloyd, I want you to be big about this... the world is full of love tonight, no woman is safe...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: ... and Bill. Especially Bill. Eve did that, too.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: You know, she probably means well, after all...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: She is a louse.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: That depends.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I mean really, deeply angry...

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: I don't think I could be.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Well. I don't want to play "Cora."

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Now wait a minute, you're always so touchy about his plays, it isn't the part - it's a great part. And a fine play. But not for me anymore - not a foursquare, upright, downright, forthright married lady.

turns.speaker: LLOYD
turns.text: What's your being married got to do with it?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: It means I've finally got a life to live! I don't have to play parts I'm too old for - just because I've got nothing to do with my nights!  I know you've made plans. I'll make it up to you, believe me. I'll tour a year with this one, anything - only you do understand - don't you, Lloyd?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Hello..

turns.speaker: OPERATOR'S VOICE
turns.text: We are ready with your call to Beverly Hills...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Call, what call?

turns.speaker: OPERATOR'S VOICE
turns.text: It this Templeton 89970? Miss Margo Channing?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: That's right, but I don't understand-

turns.speaker: OPERATOR'S VOICE
turns.text: We are ready with the call you placed for 12 midnight, California time, to Mr. William Sampson in Beverly Hills...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I placed...?

turns.speaker: OPERATOR'S VOICE
turns.text: Go ahead, please...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: "Liebestraum."

turns.speaker: PIANIST
turns.text: I just played it.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Play it again.

turns.speaker: PIANIST
turns.text: But that was the fourth straight time.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Then this will be five. I suppose you think I'm too drunk to count.

turns.speaker: PIANIST
turns.text: No. You're just crazy about "Liebestraum."

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: "Liebestraum."

turns.speaker: PIANIST
turns.text: Look, Miss Channing... it's kind of depressing. If you don't mind my saying so, everybody's kind of dying on the vine...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: My dear Horowitz. In the first place, I'm paying you union scale. Second, it's my piano. Third, if everybody doesn't like kind of dying on the vine, they can get off the vine and go home. "Liebestraum."

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Make it Bergdorf Goodman... and now everything is on its proper shelf, eh, Max? Done up in little ribbons. I could die right now and nobody'd be confused. How about you, Max?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: How about me what?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Supposed you dropped dead. What about your inventory?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: I ain't gonna die. Not with a hit.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Margo. You by any chance got bicarbonate of soda in the house?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Poor Max. Heartburn?  It's that Miss Caswell. I don't know why she doesn't give Addison heartburn.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Let the rest of the world beat their brains out for a buck. It's friends that count. And I got friends.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I love you, Max. I really mean it. I love you. Come to the pantry.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Here you are, Maxie dear. One good burp and you'll be rid of that Miss Caswell...

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: The situation I'm in ain't the kind you can belch your way out. I made a promise...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Miss Caswell?  What?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: An audition for the part we're replacing. What's-her-name, your sister...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Well, if she can act, she might not be bad. She looks like she might burn down a plantation...

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: I feel right now like there's one burning in me.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: When's the audition?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: A couple of weeks.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I tell you what. Why don't I read with her?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Would you?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Anything to help you out, Max.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: This is real cooperation. I appreciate it.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Not at all. And you could do me a big favor, if you would-

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: All you got to do is name it.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Give Eve Harrington job in you office.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: You get quick action, don't you?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Margo, I wouldn't think of taking that girl away from you...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: You said yourself my inventory was in good shape - all of my merchandise put away. To keep her here with nothing to do - I'd be standing in her way... and you need her, Max.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: But what could she do?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: She'd be a great help - read scripts, interview people you have to see, get rid of the ones you don't have to... you'd be a man of leisure-

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Well...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Think of your health, Max - more time to relax out in the fresh air at a race track...

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: I don't know if this would be a wise move...

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Promise.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: I promise.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: That's my Max.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: This is for lawyers to talk about, this concerns a run-of-the-play contract, and this you can't rewrite or ad lib!

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Are you threatening me with legal action, Mr. Fabian?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Are you breaking the contract?

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Answer my question!

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Who am I to threaten? I'm a dying man.

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: I didn't hear you.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: I said I'm a dying man!

turns.speaker: MARGO
turns.text: Not until the last drugstore has sold its last pill!

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: What the hell were you doing rewriting my story--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --I sure couldn't hurt it, could I?--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --it was fine the way it was--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --it was bullshit the way it was--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --I have to stand here and listen to the staff correspondent from Virginia?--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --what have you been here, nine months?--I been in this business since I was sixteen--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --and you've had some fucking meteoric rise, that's for sure--by the time you turn forty you might be the head of the Montana bureau--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --you only got the job because both you and Bradlee went to Yale--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --Bradlee went to Harvard--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --they're all the same, all those Ivy League places--they teach you about striped ties and suddenly you're smart--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --I'm smart enough to know my story was solid--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --mine's better--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --no way--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --read 'em both and you'll see--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: What is it about my writing that's so rotten?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Mainly it has to do with your choice of words.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Carl?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Yeah?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Fuck you, Carl.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: You heard?  They put us both on the break-in thing. Simons liked the way we worked together.  Listen, I'm sorry I said your story was bullshit.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: It's OK; I'm sorry I called you a failure.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Forget it, the main thing--  --did you call me a failure?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: I was sure trying.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: All right, what do we know?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Let me lay a little theory on you--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --I'm not interested in theory. What do we know? For example, Hunt's disappeared.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Well, Barker tried to get blueprints of the Miami Convention Center and the air-conditioning system.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: And McCord was carrying an application for college press credentials for the Democratic convention.  The Times has got to be full of it-- it can't be crazy Cubans.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: What, though?  It can't be the Republicans--he'd never allow something as stupid as this, not when he's gonna slaughter McGovern anyway.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Right. Nixon didn't get where he got by being dumb--  --listen, that was a Watergate question--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Hey?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Hmm.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: What do you think he meant, this particular incident? Were there others? How would we find out? You know anyone important?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: I lived here all my life, I got a million contacts, but they're all bus boys and bellhops.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --what do you think?--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --Hunt doesn't seem like your ordinary consultant.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Maybe a political operative of some sort--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --a spy, you mean?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: It makes sense; Hunt worked for the C.I.A. and the White House was paranoid about Teddy Kennedy.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: You think they are confidential? I don't know anything about how this town works, I haven't lived here a year yet.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: We need a sympathetic face.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: July of '71.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: About the past year.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: That was fun.  What now?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: I met a Presidential aide once at a social occasion.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: And you haven't called him?--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: The fucking New York Times.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Goddamnit--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --I'm trying--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --fifteen phone calls--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: ---fifteen or more phone calls from the burglars in Miami to Gordon Liddy at CREEP--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Why didn't we get that?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Christ, and I even know somebody at the phone company--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --you do?--with access to records?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: See her?  Get anything?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: For the paper, no; for us, plenty.  I waited a long time and finally this big guy--I guess a bodyguard-- he left and I knocked and she remembered me, we talked awhile.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: And?--And?--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --she was panicked, Carl--every time I mentioned Watergate, you could tell.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Were you eyebrow reading?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: It was there. I just don't get it; a CREEP secretary being scared, that's one thing. But what does the wife of one of the most powerful men in America have to be afraid of...?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Who's first?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Alphabetically, on the CREEP phone list, Miss Helen Abbott of South George Street.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: I don't get it... this really was my turf...

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: You're not a kid anymore.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: My first day as a copy boy I was sixteen and wearing my only grown-up suit--it was cream colored. At 2:30 the head copy boy comes running up to me and says, "My God, haven't you washed the carbon paper yet? If it's not washed by three, it'll never by dry for tomorrow."  And I said, "Am I supposed to do that?" and he said, "Absolutely, it's crucial." So I run around and grab all the carbon paper from all the desks and take it to the men's room. I'm standing there washing it and it's splashing all over me and the editor comes in to take a leak, and he says, "What the fuck do you think you're doing?" And I said, "It's 2:30. I'm washing the carbon paper."  Just wanted you to know I've done dumber things than get us lost, that's all.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: This is terrific work, if you like rejection.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: I never scared anyone before.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: It's not us, they were scared before we got there.  What do we know?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Facts or theory?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Anything you've got.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: We know there's got to be something or they wouldn't be so panicked.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: And that something's got to be more than just Hunt, Liddy, and the five burglars--those indictments are gonna be bullshit when they come down. What else do we know?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: I just wish we knew when someone would talk to us, that's all.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: We never reveal our sources, which is why you can talk to us.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: It's safe, try it, you'll see.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: We understand your problem--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --you believe in the President, you wouldn't ever want to do anything disloyal.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: We appreciate your position--really.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: I hate both parties.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: And I'm a Republican.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Republican?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Who'd you vote for?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: When?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Nixon.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Did he just say what I think he said?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: You voted for him.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: I  couldn't believe what she told me. Eight cups of coffee worth.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Go on, go on--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --we've got to find out who the five guys are--the five with access to the slush fund--they were aware of the break-in.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Then tomorrow's grand jury indictments will just be bullshit.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: It goes very high--we've got to find out where--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --we will--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --she was really paranoid, the bookkeeper.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: That happens to people.  OK, go on.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: How do you want to handle Sloan?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: You mean, who's going to play the mean M.P. and who's going to be the nice one?  Whichever.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: He's another Ivy Leaguer so he'll probably expect you to be understanding--might surprise him if you're not.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: You want me to be the bastard.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: And I'll just shitkick in my usual way.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Think Sloan's back?  What's wrong?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Nothing--I just found out that Jeb Magruder from CREEP is a bigger bike freak than I am.  I never like it when the other guy's human...

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --there had to be a White House overseer--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --Colson.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Look--five men controlled that slush fund as CREEP--three of them we've got, Mitchell, Stans, Magruder, and we're pretty sure of Kalmbach.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: We'd like to wait til we have all five before we print it.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --The L.A. Times has a huge interview with Baldwin--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --the lookout in the Motor Inn?--  --he say anything we don't know?--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --just that a lot of reports were sent to CREEP, but he doesn't name who, not here anyway--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Goddamnit--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --shit--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --we gotta top the Times--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --I know, I know--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --if we could name the guys got the reports, we'd be ahead again--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --shit, who do we know?--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --I know a lawyer at Justice--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --has he got an ax?--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --almost every source we've used has been Republican, this guy's a card- carrying Democrat.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Then he's got an ax.  Call him anyway.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --I want you to shut up and listen to me--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --I haven't said anything--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --for the first time I'm beginning to feel like a fucking reporter-- Woodward, I got a tip. A guy called me up with a tip--  --someone named Donald Segretti contacted a bunch of lawyers and asked them if they'd like to go to work with him screwing up the Democrats, dirty tricks, shit like that. The FBI knows about Segretti-- Howard Hunt made a bunch of phone calls to him--they interrogated him, but on account of Segretti wasn't involved with the break-in, they didn't follow through. But Segretti did a lot of traveling--he called these lawyers from different places, and he told them the Republicans knew what he was doing.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: How high up, which Republicans?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: That's what we've got to find out, but Segretti went to Southern Cal. and so did a bunch of Nixon men--

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: --Haldeman I know, who else?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Dwight Chapin, Nixon's appointments chief--he knew Segretti in school. Maybe I'm crazy, but this is the first time any of this starts to make sense. What were the three theories?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: The burglary was done by Cubans or Democrats or Republicans.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Now the reason no one believed the Republicans is because there wasn't any reason, they were so far ahead. But Segretti was talking to these other lawyers a year before the break- in.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: So maybe Watergate wasn't really about Watergate--maybe that was just a piece--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --because a year before, the Republicans weren't ahead, not in the polls, Muskie was running ahead of Nixon then. Before he self- destructed.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: If he self-destructed.

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: Segretti criss-crossed the country over ten times in six months--and never stayed anyplace over a night or two.  Switch to another station, huh? You're driving me crazy with that.

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: Segovia begged me for me secret but I said, "No, Andres, you'll have to try and make it without me."

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: California, Illinois, Florida, New Hampshire--all the major Democratic primary states.  Why does everything you play sound the same?

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: --'cause I only know four chords--

turns.speaker: BERNSTEIN
turns.text: What would you have done?

turns.speaker: WOODWARD
turns.text: You asking would I have been one of the President's men?  I would have been.
